Literature Review: Temperature is a critical environmental factor that significantly influences plant growth, development, and distribution across the globe. As climate change continues to alter global temperature patterns, understanding how plants perceive and respond to temperature fluctuations has become increasingly important for both ecological research and agricultural applications. This literature review focuses on recent advances in our understanding of temperature sensing mechanisms in plants, with a particular emphasis on four major pathways in Arabidopsis thaliana: vernalization, cold stress, thermomorphogenesis, and heat stress.Vernalization, the process by which prolonged exposure to cold temperatures promotes flowering, has been extensively studied in A. thaliana. Recent research has revealed that the epigenetic regulation of FLOWERING LOCUS C (FLC) plays a crucial role in this process. Heo and Sung (2011) demonstrated that prolonged cold exposure leads to the accumulation of histone modifications at the FLC locus, resulting in its stable repression and the subsequent promotion of flowering. This epigenetic memory of cold exposure allows plants to align their reproductive timing with favorable environmental conditions.Cold stress response mechanisms have also been a focus of intense research. The ICE-CBF-COR pathway has emerged as a central regulator of cold acclimation in plants. Shi et al. (2018) showed that the transcription factor ICE1 is stabilized under cold conditions, leading to the activation of C-REPEAT BINDING FACTOR (CBF) genes. CBFs, in turn, induce the expression of COLD-REGULATED (COR) genes, which encode proteins that protect cellular structures from cold damage. Interestingly, recent work by Ding et al. (2019) has revealed that RNA thermosensors play a role in regulating CBF expression, providing a direct link between temperature perception and gene regulation.Thermomorphogenesis, the process by which plants alter their growth and development in response to ambient temperature changes, has gained significant attention in recent years. The phytochrome B (phyB) photoreceptor has been identified as a key temperature sensor in this process. Jung et al. (2016) demonstrated that the rate of phyB thermal reversion from its active Pfr form to its inactive Pr form is temperature-dependent, allowing it to function as a thermosensor. This temperature-dependent conformational change affects the interaction of phyB with PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTORS (PIFs), which are central regulators of thermomorphogenesis.Heat stress response mechanisms in plants have also been extensively studied. The heat shock transcription factors (HSFs) play a crucial role in activating heat stress-responsive genes. Ohama et al. (2017) showed that HSFA1 acts as a master regulator of the heat stress response, activating a cascade of other HSFs and heat shock proteins (HSPs). Recent work by Li et al. (2020) has revealed that the histone variant H2A.Z plays a role in temperature sensing during heat stress. They found that H2A.Z-containing nucleosomes are evicted from heat-responsive gene promoters at high temperatures, facilitating gene activation.An emerging theme in plant temperature sensing is the involvement of RNA-based mechanisms. Chung et al. (2016) demonstrated that temperature-dependent alternative splicing of FLOWERING LOCUS M (FLM) transcripts regulates flowering time in response to ambient temperature changes. This finding highlights the potential of RNA structures to act as direct temperature sensors in plants.Protein phase separation has also been implicated in temperature sensing. Mittag et al. (2018) showed that the prion-like domain of EARLY FLOWERING 3 (ELF3) undergoes temperature-dependent phase transitions, affecting its ability to form biomolecular condensates and regulate gene expression. This discovery opens up new avenues for understanding how temperature information is transduced into cellular responses.Recent advances in high-throughput sequencing technologies have enabled genome-wide studies of temperature responses in plants. Cortijo et al. (2017) used ChIP-seq and RNA-seq to map the global changes in chromatin accessibility and gene expression in response to temperature changes, revealing complex regulatory networks involved in temperature sensing and response.As our understanding of plant temperature sensing mechanisms grows, so does the potential for applying this knowledge to crop improvement. Zhu et al. (2018) demonstrated that manipulating the expression of CBF genes in rice could enhance its cold tolerance without significant yield penalties, highlighting the potential for engineering climate-resilient crops.In conclusion, recent research has revealed a complex network of molecular mechanisms involved in plant temperature sensing, including epigenetic regulation, RNA thermosensors, protein conformational changes, and phase transitions. These diverse mechanisms allow plants to integrate temperature information into their developmental programs and stress responses. As climate change continues to pose challenges to plant survival and crop productivity, further research into these temperature sensing mechanisms will be crucial for developing strategies to mitigate its impacts on agriculture and natural ecosystems.
